replies.text: Treasury shares are a sneaky way to reissue stock to management, which is often to the benefit of managementdirectors, and detriment of owners shareholders. At the same time they use this mechanism, they use another where by they reserve a block of shares every few years for issuance as payment to managementemployeesdirectors. Treasury stock comes in especially handy here because they dont have to file any SEC notices or make any public statements, like you would if you were issuing new shares to cover the same scheme. The company can buy back enough shares each year to compensate for all the shares they are handing out cheapfree to insiders. Its an actuarial magic trick. From a birds eye view, it doesnt look like dilution. Its even a great sound bite buybacks, hey look at how much we care about owners! but shareholders are very much losing out in the long run. Buy back shares at market rate through the front door, with owners money. Hand those same shares out the back door at bargain basement price to managersdirectors. Shazam! Share count stays about the same! Ever wonder why with record earnings something like a 70 yr high record earnings, companies are still only paying dividends that equate to at best 4 no better than a 10yr US Treasury? Wheres all those record earnings going? Oh look, the CEO found a bunch of extra shares that fell off the back of this DEF14A truck, at half price....

Treasury stock is sometimes used to grant stock options to key employees. Canceled shares cannot be reissued perhaps that would be attractive to stockholders who do not actively participate in the business and dont wish to have their shares diluted in the future.
Both ways can and do happen. Usually theyre cancelled because its ultimately the decision of the shareholders what happens, and shareholders prefer to limit the possibility of future dilution.

I dont genuinely know the answer to this. My guess is that the point of a buyback is to increase the value of the outstanding shares. Its a way of returning capital to shareholders. Cancelling the shares increases the degree of ownership of the company that outstanding shares have, which implicitly means their intrinsic value increases.
Whats the difference? Companies can buy them back and sell them later, or cancel them and create more shares later.
The other magic that share buybacks can have is internal buybacks of insider held shares, so it doesnt tank the market price when they are cashed in.

You are complicating it too much. Share buyback and issuing dividend are identical, while issuance to insider is the same to paying a cash wage. With the exception of tax purpose ofc. Generally speaking no one is losing out in the long run, its just really annoying if you regularly sniff through their financials. That been said there is a magic trick, a lot of compensation, especially ones offered to Csuits, are tied to stock price. This means buybacks directly increases CEO compensations compare to dividend, which can be especially bad if the shareholdersboards are less financially sophisticated. E just remembered share issuance is also better for cashflow, but thats about it

Theres a view that a Dem victory would be positive and perhaps it is initially, but everyone also thought in late 2020 that green energy was a sure thingeasy money and piled into it only to have January 2021 be the top in things like ICLN. I think too many people are still looking at EVs like its the 202021 disruptive growth bubble while the market has returned to the view that the auto industry is a competitive, cost intensive and generally not great business and EVs dont change that. I mean, look at Aston Martin flirting with 0 again would be bankruptcy 8. Musk has said countless times over the years that the auto industry is an incredibly difficult business and that Tesla has narrowly avoided bankruptcy at times. The automobile industry has not been good for investors, with a couple of noteworthy exceptions 1 Ferrari, because its an ultra high end luxury company that happens to sell cars and 2 Tesla, because of whether you like him or not Musk.
Take a look at BYD, Chinese EVs that have the lions share of their market and expanding.

Its pretty simple, you either think they are a good company or not. Read the quarterly reports, balance sheet, understand their financing and debt, who owns and what are they doing with it, and what the future of the EV market looks like and premium cars. If you havent already done that, you probably shouldnt own individual stocks at all. Going to Reddit with a what should I do here and no details is a red flag to your financial future.

RIVN isnt going to do anything until their new factory is online. That wont be till 2028 according their estimates assuming they make it till then. Obviously investors are getting tired of the cash burn and how slow they are moving toward profit given they knew what it would take. I like that they are careful but its well known that you need scale to turn a profit. That should have been top priority over a new platform. In other words, they should have started working on that factory 2 years ago. There is probably little to no reason to invest in RIVN right now. Might as well wait till 2026 unless you are fishing for a buyout.

The most recent cvswalgreens failing. most of their clients died of Covid19 Are you so hungry for something else that RIVN is worth a loss nobody likes a loser their cash management is not the best but yours might not be as well. You can slowly enter into something else over time and the pain is way less than buy all now and wait then you can stay current on that companies status, never buy a share without looking it over first. As long as you have extra money coming in you can always add more to what peaks your interest......if you sell All now Id sell half at a time if you need the money for rent you could very well be entering another turd. It takes time in the market to gain and RIVN as well as the money you threw at it are only a few years invested. I see Rivian vehicles driving around where I live so thats a start. Most EV is having trouble getting parts right now I believe TSLA is prioritized based on sheer volume of the parts they need thats how businesses work. but TSLA cant monopolize the market and not everyone will want a Tesla but they are the cheapest but still not as profitable as Mercedes Benz. Dont just make a decision, think about every aspect of everything you are doing because if you do make the correct choice Uncle Sam will be sitting there waiting to take his cut so plan ahead........heck its only money!!!

Why did you hold so long as that is a big drop to stomach? If you sell immediately to tax loss harvest and buy it back on 30 days you may miss the rise in shares if the Dems win in November which will likely be good for EVs and green energy companies. Might want to wait it out since youve waiting this long and the election is less than a month away. If you are sick of the name and seeing the red in your portfolio move on after the election because there are better opportunities. If you like the name buy the equivalent share amount now and then sell the expensive shares in 31 days to tax harvest. The R2 might change things like the model 3 did for Tesla reaching profitability so its worth the risk to me. Good luck to you.

The insurance for the waste is one of the biggest prohibitions to nuclear waste. It essentially needs to be guaranteed forever, this results in the only ones willing to take the risk being states and countries.

It is not 75000 years to store waste. Low and intermediate level waste is stored for 30 years in cooldown pools before being buried is ceramic pucks, and hight level waste is stored for 50 years before being buried. High level waste loses 99.9 of its reactivity in 40 years. The worst high level waste is back to background level within 100010000 years. The Navy has stored all of its waste generated over the last 60 years of nuclear power in a single spent copper mine. 95 of waste is low level. 0.2 is high level, with intermediate making up the difference. 30 percent of all used fuel is reprocessed for reuse in reactors and a small percentage is refined for medical use. As for the cost. Long term storage for is estimated 10 of the total cost of the reactors lifetime expense, and is required by the government to be set aside to cover all costs.

Nuclear waste is an extremely over exagerated problem. The entirety of highly dangerous nuclear waste produced in France from the past 40 years fits into a single cube with sides measuring 15 meters. And Its the most nuclearized country in the world, and the total amount of carbon free energy produced for so little waste is absolutely outstanding.

Fat cats just didnt have the time to get the fuel so we were told solar and other bullshit is the way. Wut? Nuke was killed by NIMBYism. The fear of another Chernobyl, TMI, etc... forced the industry to be regulated to the point that for most companies it wasnt financially viable. The company I work for used to own Talen energy mentioned in this article the reason it was sold off is because it was just dead weight back then. Perfect example...at the Susquehanna plant mentioned, we had to keep two fleets of excavators on hand in case of a meltdown and pay for upkeep, maintenance, etc... It was literally redundancy for a black swan event, wild. This is the reason that Exelon has basically been the name in the game in nuke generation in the US. My old boss used to head up exelons nuke operations the only way they were able to make it profitable was through acquisition and absolutely ruthless standardization...they acquired a new plant and would implement the playbook...execsemployees who pushed back were gone. Same service intervals, same vendors for IT systems, same schemes, same excavator, same everything across the entire fleet. My company, as many others have long said nuke is the answer...with reasonable regulation. SMR and the involvement of big tech is bringing that conversation to the forefront. Nuke and nuke adjacent industries like utilities are great play at the moment. Same with NG, but thats a whole other discussion.

On top of that, the fact is the more you engage in a risky activity the greater the odds of something bad happening from said activity even if the odds are really really low. i.e. the average driver could correctly boast having a 100 safety record, but obviously youd rightly laugh in their face if they insisted that means theres zero chance that theyll ever get into a car accident. Even if you have a bunch of very safe drivers on the road, the more very safe drivers you have on the road the greater the odds that one of those very safe drivers will get into an accident, it happens every day because theres millions of them on the road. That above paragraph isnt fear mongering about nuclear energy, its statistical odds.

Your fallacy is in attributing the causes of previous nuclear incidents all to operator error. Humans make mistakes, of course, and Chernobyl management was definitely negligent and reckless. However, what made Chernobyl a disaster was shoddy reactor design that wouldve never been possible in the West. I mean, hitting the shutdown reactor button is what caused the Chernobyl reactors to explode! Same goes to Fukushima with its backup generator design and way too tiny tsunami seawalls. Its not just the Wests operational practices that have made nuclear energy so safe here. Its that reactor facilities have been designed with passive safety in mind to prevent operator error from ever causing a disaster, and the next generation nuclear technology takes that to another level. Its like saying cars in the 50s were so dangerous because even minor accidents could kill or cause severe injury, so people just shouldnt drive. Sure, operators need to improve, but the cars themselves could get a whole lot safer, and they have!

There technical limitations to using cameras that go beyond needs more data. The point clouds created by Lidar data are precise measures, capable of operating at any level of light, and arent hampered by various sources of noise in the surroundings which can cause problems with cameras, such as lights and the like. Further, stereoscopic measurement is essentially inference IE, not a direct measure of distance or timing, but rather on an inferred model based on parallax and relationships. Lidar will always be more accurate than a camera for the simple fact that Lidar is basically a direct measurement, whereas cameras for such cases are an indirect method. You can get fairly accurate with optical cameras, but never nearly so was with Lidar. Stereoscopic and orthological mapping using cameras is processor heavy far moreso than Lidar point clouds, requires more time for data processing, requires actual light to be present, and can get confused by stray light sources. While both have limitations, particularly in rainy or foggy conditions, these limitations are generally the same. The fundamental issue with cameras for FSD isnt one of data, its one of actual technological and physical limitations which are essentially impossible to overcome.

Kind of irrelevant atm, theyre running it as a tech demonstration not a business. More important is the actual cost to waymo per ride, including amortization of hardware, software and dev costs. Because that will determine if its actually a viable business model or just another silicon valley solution in search of a problem. My guess is its not. Drivers arent the only cost to a taxi business and do a lot of stuff you take for granted cleaning, arranging servicing and off duty storage etc. Self driving taxis remove the driver cost but then add in a whole bunch of extra costs cleaners, fleet managers etc plus the rather sizable costs of the extra hardware plus software and dev costs. If its viable at all it would only be at huge scale with immense capital costs. With the inevitable low margins its hard to see who that business would appeal to. The benefit to the customer is also marginal. Is your driverless taxi offering your a significantly better service or outcome than a drivered one? No. They both get you to where you want to go for a small amount of money. Thats it. And for cities they will simply make congestion even worse. America doesnt want to hear this but the solution for moving large numbers of people around quickly and cheaply is more public transport and fewer cars of any kind.

Lidar works in lowlight conditions, and is more or less a direct measure of distance. Optical methods with cameras perform poorly in low light conditions, and require orthological modeling to determine distance. A lot more can go wrong with optical cameras than Lidar in determining distances due to the far, far more strenuous processing requirements of optical systems that also tend to be far less accurate. Its a bit more apt to say that cameras dont have any particular advantage over Lidar at all aside from cost, and Lidar is a more reliable system overall with fewer fail points to be concerned with. It has some similar limitations in terms of fog and the like, but the biggest difference is that Lidar gives actual distances well, they give actual time between shooting the laser out and reading it, which is innturn calculated to a distance whereas cameras infer distances you have multiple overlapping images that create a 3D model that you can measure in.

I have two different cars with driverassist cruise control. The Volvo with radar performs excellently in most conditions. In heavy rain, it will disengage before I can react. The BMW that has cameras only disengages Driver assist driving under bridges with a shadow when there are no lines on the road and other scenarios. My daughters Subaru with cameras is a little better, but it is clear to me radar improves reliability. I am no expert on radar, but I use a car with it. The power puck, the glasses and the wristband thing. Its not just glasses. Its 3 things. The glasses are too thick for prime time. They will have to figure out how to chop that thickness almost in half, which could be impossible. They also need to dramatically increase the resolution. Increasing the FOV would be great, but I think theyre pretty much hitting a hard limit with it. Still a solid decade away from a real AR glasses contender

Watching media in a VR headset is a really cool experience, but apps like Netflix either arent good or arent available in the headset, so you often have to use the browser for them. Thats another case where having a high powered PC makes the headset better because you can just mirror your computer screen. Theres exercise and productivity uses for it, but I dont have much experience with that. Some people love it, but both those cases work better if you can see your environment. Unfortunately the passthrough is just not quite there yet to make it usable for long periods of time for me personally. Thats why Meta is making glasses so you dont need passthrough. Even though theres benefits, its hard to convince people to do their entertainment, exercise, and productivity inside of VRAR when the drawbacks are so apparent. Again, I love my Quest 3 though and recommend it to people, but theres a ways to go before it will get widespread adoption. Itll get there, Meta is doing a great job imo in innovating in this space.
RD costs money, how unexpected!
Have you tried using it
Yes because they were basically the quest 2.5 the quest 3 and now the quest 3s are better than the Pro and cheaper
Facebook is an advertising company, so yes.
lol. How about all the past evidence with the metaverse??
There is. They dont exist. So yeah, there is no reason to expect they can deliver that.

Theres a lot of reason to think that. Take your first example, traffic directions. They have to figure out exactly where youre looking and seamlessly embed the directions into it to make it not drive you insane. If its just the same map as the phone but overlaid, youre creating a blind spot. If there is even the slightest lag where the arrow drags, its going to make you crazy and cause problems. Thats before we even begin to talk about the liability of something impeding vision while driving. Having played significantly with OCR Optical character recognition trying to apply it for a project at work, I have no faith at all it could translate the text on random signs into another language. It likely wont even get the original language right. The AR art displays is an interesting idea though. I could also see it being used as an enhancement for Pokemon GO style games. The other thing you have to think about is that a lot of this processing would need to be done locally by the glasses. If it requires too much processing and has to be sent to the cloud and back, the lag is going to mess with you pretty bad. I think youre on the right track for use cases, but I think your ideas are way ahead of where the technology actually is.
This is incorrect, but AR will be the bigger of the two.
Its been a stepping stone for over a decade. I remember magic leap being around the corner.

One of the most popular consoles to ever be released was the Wii, which was explicitly designed and marketed around the idea that it was a more physical way to play games. That being said, the physical requirements of VR are overstated. The vast majority of games can be played sitting down with only limited physical movement. Think using gyro control on the Dual SenseSwitch Joycons.
Its going to take a jack with direct interface to brain. Then you can eliminate all the pesky movement stuff by hijacking those pathways.
Its not the use case thats lacking, its the right hardwaresoftware combo, which will eventually be realized
Connect being the keyword. The Oculus 2 demonstrated the appeal of having a zerocord setup. 6ghz made that possible, on PC, without the latency hit.

Again this is completely incorrect. Print media pushed back on PCs and the Internet because it was a threat to their business model, but the general public saw the utility for things like printing, financials, etc. everyone was moving to computers at work, so its not like there was no frame of reference

This is the metaverse.
They all already exist.

Just so you know, your phone can already do AR directions via Google Maps. Like, it already exists. Itll just be infinitely more convenient to do it via AR glasses than holding up your phone like you currently have to.

About the traffic directions most newer cars made in this decade already have AR screens builtinto their windscreen showing you both your current speed and directions. Mine have one and it works flawlessly, I love that I never have to look away from the road. About translating the text on signs our phones can already do that, the advantage of the AR glasses would be that you do not have to occupy one of your hands for it. About the processing it is not much. Our phones can already process these types of information. I honestly think that we are probably less than a decade away AR glasses replacing phones.
They have to figure out exactly where youre looking Very easy stuff. The glasses already know this.
And itll be another decade before AR is consumer ready. This is an insanely difficult tech to fit into a pair of glasses.

It was, but when the Wii came out gaming was a much smaller culture it wasnt anywhere near as normalized for pro gaming, or even gaming being considered an actual hobby. The Wii did well cause they found some fun games that worked for it there was a lot of other similar move both Xbox and play station had one that never took off
The right hardware needs to have the form factor of glasses for mainstream adoption, and we are a long way from that.

The general public was uninterested in home PCs until the 1990s prior to that it was only early adoptersearly majority buying home PCs and many of them ended up collecting dust because people didnt know what to do with them andor found them too difficult to use.

Print media loved PCs in the early days, it massively reduced the cost of making printed materials. It wasnt until the late 90s when the internet emerged as a threat. Its kind of shocking how much dumb, obviously wrong bullshit I read in this subreddit.
Im not denying that but when making that claim one has to take into account the whole and not just their own bubble.

Something tells me that the company making 130 billion a year, with nearly 4 billion users and one of the largest collections of data on humanity in the world has a long gameplan in mind that requires ignoring short term thinking. And 20 billion is nothing for a company that has allocated 50 billion towards buybacks in the past year alone
It is far too early to make such an evaluation for reality labs. Thats what I especially like about Meta, it is founder run and Zuckerberg probably knows more about his field than anybody else.

This is just wildly wrong. I dont know what to tell you. Your phone can create a map based on your GPS location and destination. The best ones can suggest destinations based on where youve been andor externally harvested data. They cannot overlay that map into your reality. You do that by virtue of moving your phone around to wherever and looking at it. As soon as you automate that, you introduce TONS of problems.

About translating the text on signs our phones can already do that, the advantage of the AR glasses would be that you do not have to occupy one of your hands for it. Dude, I write code for a living. Im not some tech illiterate. They have it, and it doesnt work well already. Go use it. You get garbage output more often than not. A projected HUD on a car windshield is far easier to get seamless than an AR HUD. You guys are just absurdly optimistic about how this shit works and the technical barriers. In any case, Im done arguing about it, if you guys want to throwoney at delusions, have at it.

The 2000s was the era of PS2, which remains one of the best selling consoles in existence. Theres been growth since then, but gaming was firmly established at that point. The Kinect was terrible and for all intents and purposes didnt actually work. The PS Move suffered from what typically happens with peripherals that arent bundled with the base SKU of a console, developers dont take full advantage of them since doing so meant reducing their potential customer pool. They arent really comparable to a console that has features that actually work and are packaged into the base unit. Though the PS Move controllers saw a second life bundled with PSVR, which could be called a success.
and we are a long way from that. I would say 5 years give or take. And it would take years for the competition to catch up if Meta captures that market first. Its worth taking the shot imo
Those tools you use were built with PyTorch, which is from Meta.
Tell me you never used google Vr map without telling me. Seriously, try using it when you are in subway under ground.

Again, to be super clear, you can absolutely overlay Google Maps directions on to reality through your phone camera via the AR function in Google Maps on your phone. This already exists and it works pretty well except for having to hold your phone up all the time.

I was also a senior software developer before I became an investor meaning I dont have to work anymore. I would and probably will, in the future, if a good opportunity arises bet serious money on that VRAR devices will become mainstream and will start to really replace monitors and phones in the next 1015 years and currently I am not even invested in META. We will see which one of us was right in a decade or two, haha!
AR glasses I can see. VR glasses are a ways off. They will need significant basic scientific advances.

Just because most ppl use pytorch doesnt mean that meta is somehow the leader. It doesnt give them ownership of what you built with their open source framework, nor do they earn any revenue from ppl using pytorch. Its not like nvidia where they have CUDA
Seriously, try using it when you are in subway under ground. Try using it when youre responsible for not killing someone.
Im not sure VR glasses are worth the RD. A VR headset does the job just fine already
It helps attract talent, and you get free labor from the opensource community. Just look at Google with their TensorFlow, and youll see the difference
Try using it when youre responsible for not killing someone. You are literally always responsible for not killing someone.

This is the gap between vr enthusiasts and everyone else. VR enthusiasts are generally happy and think VR just needs moderate incremental improvements to be mainstream. For most people, the headsets are tiring, and very inconvenient. Something people wear for a little as a gimmick, then gathers dust. With a complete redesign needed for VR to take off.
Thats an absurdly disingenuous argument and you know it.

In the same period the Reality Labs segment made a 16.7B loss. Without the RL segment, META would have made 75.5B in operating income. At current prices the stock would trade at 17.6x operating income. METAs earnings are stellar and this is despite this massive moneylosing segment. The highest stock price META had achieved before the crash was 380 in September 21. Today the share price is 490, or 30 higher. If you call that 3 years between then and now, thats a roughly 9 annualized return. But we can actually look at their actual buying price. From this source the average buy price in 2021 was 330, which comes out to 13 annualized return. So the buybacks during seemingly bubble territory turned out to be decent capital allocation in the end. The SP 500 is only about 20 higher than its peak valuation, so those buybacks were marketbeating. Now consider the buybacks in 2022 at 173 average, before the 182 rally to todays share price...

I took a massive position in meta last week, just before the crash. Wish i had waited a couple of hours as the jobs data came out and the stock price crashed... but overall im bullish. Its a great company. It has good leadership, meta has managed to stay ahead of the curve for the last 20 years and its still growing. Metas suite of products are still relevant across multiple generations and their platforms are generally considered the most effective platforms for ad spend. Meta is also competitive with other players Google, apple etc. For instance, the AI lama chatbot that theyve introduced is actually pretty good... and they have big ambitions for it to be the most used AI tool by December. Im reasonably certain they will be able to monetize AI directly and indirectly... directly though AI powered ads maybe tiered pricing or subscription models and indirectly through more precise data analysis, efficiencies etc. Their VR spend is pretty excessive IMO but it looks like Mark wants to create a new paradigm for interaction and has high conviction in this investment. To be honest, until VR is made significantly more comfortable to use, its not going to take off, but I think they are working on creating hardware that is more comfortable to use. Im not as skeptical as I used to be, and I can imagine a lot of use cases where VR could be very useful. For instance, I live in a country 25 hours away from my immediate family. If theres a VR headset that allows me to feel like Im meeting my family in close proximity in a VR holiday location Id be game. But this is contingent on all of us having comfortable head sets and price continues to be a factor that they will need lower to see mass adoption of VR. The AR glasses though, I can see more immediate value and uptake. Im considering buying them now. Im bullish on the stock in the medium to long term 12 months 48 months. I have no idea what the stock is going to do in the short term given macro environment. But I think online gaming with VR, space requirements, and quality of the visualization in the headset need to improve. Would be great if I can get on an omnidirectional treadmill and play madden

replies.text: Look at all your essential expenses per month rent, car payment, food, etc. Essential. Add it up. Multiply by 3 or 6 to be safer. Keep this amount in cash in a highyield savings account. You do not have this money. This is your safety net. You are walking on a highwire in life, and something may happen lose your job, get injured and cant work, your parent is dying and you decide you must care for them full time, etc. This money catches you when you fall. Some bad shit will happen in life. Hopefully not permanentlylifedebilitating, but some really turbulent times are almost guaranteed. Walk the highwire of life with a net.

To answer your question about waiting 13 business days for emergencies. There are very few true emergencies where you absolutely need thousands of dollars CASH right this second. A credit card can be used for everything truly emergent, then the HYSA gets transferred into the Checking to cover the CC bill later. However, having truly liquid cash in a local bank or credit Union still isnt a horrible idea. Even if its just 500. Some people carry like 3k in their local bank for this reason.

Everyone keeps their emergency funds in money markets or I bonds. 36 depends on risk tolerance, job stability, employability, etc. Personally, I lived through 2008 and watched really smart people stay unemployed for two years. My emergency fund is larger.

SPAXX is a great place to put your emergency fund, especially if you have a cash back credit card from Fidelity. Thats where I keep most of mine. I also keep a a few hundred to a couple thousand in physical cash in case of an emergency where my cards are inaccessible.

You can keep your emergency fund in a money market fund like SPAXX Ikeep about half of my emergency fund there. Investing all of it in the market is highly risky even in a dividend ETF like SCHD. With my personal experience, I keep a years worth of salary as an emergency fund, so I would go with the 6 months because it can take a while to find a job.

You should have accessible cash, I personally use spaxx because anything really expensive is usually not due same day and you can use a credit card while money transfers. So, 6 months in spaxx and then a taxable brokerage account buying voo or something, that way you can sell and pull from that as well if something happens but its a lower risk investment that can still grow, hoping you dont have to access it.

Emergency fund is the answer to the question what do I need to pay for my lifestyle for the next 6 months if I lose my job or if the economy goes to shit?. You dont want to have to sell stocks on short notice if you lose your job or the market has tanked, so its good to have money market savings or other short term treasury style investments that you can access in that time. If you dont have a high limit credit card, youd also want to have some balance in your checking account to pay for unexpected expenses like car repairs. And going down the prepper road, you could add in cash to deal with the case where you lose your wallet or cant access electronic funds for a couple weeks, like if theres a fire, earthquake, or hurricane. Going further down the prepper road, add in physical gold that is in your possession to deal with the case where the entire financial system collapses, inflation skyrockets, currency becomes worthless, or you need to pay people to help you flee the country.

Everything youve written is pretty much spot on. Not sure about the downvotes either. Here are some answers The most common purpose of an emergency fund is to cover your personal expenses in the event your main source of income suddenly goes to zero. The recommended 36 months should depend on the expected time for you to secure a new job. For example if you are a fast food worker it may be shorter vs. an executiveCEO it may be longer. It will also depend on the job market in your industry. One risk is that the sudden loss in income can come during a recession when many others are also looking for employment. In this case it may take longer to find another job. The US would pretty much need to default on their debt for SPAXX to tank. Very low likelihood in the next 10 years and beyond. This is fine to invest in as you say you would then only need to cover the 13 business days for the money to transfer to your checking account. In my opinion a cc is a perfectly reasonable short term source of liquidity that can be paid back with your emergency fund.

Having your emergency fund in any liquid investment is okay. Dont put it in real estate that could take weeks or months to liquidate. Its best not to have it in certificates of deposit or retirement funds that would penalize a withdrawal. Any other kind of bank account or stock or mutual fund should be fine, because you could get the cash into your checking account within a few days. You might want to leave room on a credit card or keep a balance in your bank account to tide you over while investments are being sold and the proceeds transferred.

For my emergency fund I like to keep it in different levels of liquidity. In my checking account that I use every day I keep about a months worth of expenses. At the same bank I keep another month in savings. In a high yield savings at an online bank I keep another two months. With liquidity, hear me out, even 3 days can be too much. I have everything set on autopay and once or twice when I wasnt watching my checking too closely it went negative. For every transaction that hits after that the fees will add up quickly. If Im not able to transfer money instantly Id have to pay a ton in fees.
SPAXX is fine, and the size of the fund is a personal choice. You want peace of mind, and you dont want to be forced to sell a stock at a bad time because your car got totaled, or you got fired.

I keep 6 months expenses in SPAXX because if I lose my job I want to have some time to find a new one. To me a money market like SPAXX is fine. I keep about a month of expenses in my checking account and I also have credit cards. I also keep a few hundred in cash just in case of the kind of emergency where the power goes out for a long time.
If you are a single individual then three months is okay. Especially if you are working to pay down debts if you have CC debt then work of that first. But if you have a family then 6 months is better

I know youre basically just out of school, but you dont need to overoptimize all your money. Its ok to have 36 months of money not making interest. Its just insurance. And, trust me, when it rains it pours. When I first got out of college, not only would my car need new brakes, but also, the turning belt would break. Or I would need new tires. Or there would be a leak under the sink. You really should have this money easily accessible. Could it be in a spaxx or bonds, sure. You almost never need the money right now especially if you have a credit card with a high limit. But I wouldnt put it in any real etfs like SP500, etc. Because itll just be your luck that your emergency coincides with the next recession and there goes all your money.

It means you take what you spend in 1 month and multiply it by a number between 36 and keep that much in the bank for emergencies. The exact number depends on your risk tolerance and circumstances. For example, if you are in a career field where layoffs are common or it may be difficult to get a new job, you are probably closer to 6. If you are confident you can get back on your feet quickly, 3 is fine. It really does not matter where you keep this money because it should not be a significant part of your nest egg. I know it may seen like a lot of money when you are starting out, but in the grand scheme of things its really not, and the interest you make will not make a difference in your life. What is more important is that you can access this money quickly in the event of a emergency. Now if you MUST make some interest or else you cant sleep at night, you can put it in a HYSA or even a money market or the any interest generating fund. No one said it has to just sit in the bank. It is true that not that many emergencies require instant liquidity.

It means whatever you want it to mean. Its purpose is to make people think about keeping a stash of money for unplanned expenses. What those expenses are and how much you should put aside for them are entirely up to you. Given the current job market plus the fact that my employer started laying off people in small batches a year ago, my focus is on income replacement in case I get laid off! Before then, my emergency fund was more for a tree falling on my house or my cars engine exploding. I do regular maintenance and inspections on most items, so a surprise dead furnace or AC unit is unlikely. There is no consensus of what exactly an Emergency funds is , how much it should be, or where you should keep it. if you ask 10 people , youll get 20 different answers So figure out what unplanned expenses concern you, then how much you should put away for them, and finally where to keep the money. In the end, the fund is for you, and you should design it around your needs.

IMO 3 months if you have a very stable job ex governmenttenure, 6 months if you live in an atwill employment state, and 12 months if you have a housemortgage and dependents andor work in a niche field with long hiring processes. There is also debate if it should be essential living expenses, your normal expenses, or gross income. The answer depends on your risk tolerance. Additionally, while many conflate items like repairing a car and replacing a hot water heater with using emergency funds, its often because people forget to plan for semi regular expenses rather than a true emergency. For example, a tree falling through your roof is an emergency. A 30 year old roof resulting in leaks and a burst pipe is a maintenance costs you need to plan for. So sinking funds emergency funds usually results in a smaller EF. Another good rule of thumb is to male sure that your EF is at least twice your max OOP for health insurance so you can have one health scare leftover funds.

The whole idea of recommending a 3 month worth of emergency funds is just an estimate of how much a person would need for any emergency situations or contingencies. This is just like keeping some money aside for any unforeseen expense say you have an accident or say your refrigerator broke down or you have a major car repair to deal with or a health emergency. I think you did not understand this basic purpose of emergency fund. The emergency fund is not intended to earn good interest or return, so thats not a consideration. If you still want to put it in highinterest earning accounts, good for you, but thats not the objective. I agree with your point about having credit card to cover emergecies but thats also how people get in to a debt trap I dont need to explain this you know it. Lastly for some people I understand building 36 months emergency fund is difficult. For example for someone earning 5000 a month and having 3000 a month expenses, the suggested emergency fund would be in the range of 9000 to 18000. Saving 10,000 or more is not easy in the context of high inflation and lifestyle expenses we have today. So the way to get to atleast 9000 is to set aside regular sums every week say put in 200 a week and by end of the year you will reach the 10000 mark. Its not like one day you wake and say I will put 10k in emegency fund, its a slow process. Now summing up all the above the emergency funds is for emergencies its not for optimizing your returns, for that you need to do longterm investing.

6 months of essentials and a little extra. A healthy EF will be over 6 months. Essentials are things you cant live without...food, shelter, utilities, transportation, etc. As your income increases, so does the cost of your essentials so your EF needs to keep up. I always say a little extra because in an emergency you need some relief and escapes for your sanity. So although Netflix, or movie night, or that bowl of ice cream isnt essential...it sure is a reprieve from lifes stresses so build just a little of that into your EF. If you are starting out...HYSA and dont look back to keep it in. As you get more comfortable with your plan and larger EF...you can start to change it up bonds, bond etfs, bond ladders, credit card, etc I keep 12 months in HYSA, 3 in I series bonds, I have dedicated credit card for immediate expenses, and then varying degrees of ETFs for additional 6 months. Remember an Emergency could be a job loss during a market turn down, so if you have your EF in stocks or higher risk securities, that value could be substantially less than what you had planned on.

An emergency fund is simply money set aside and untouched, not to be circulated into your regular savings or accounted for whatsoever. For a lot of people, this is money to be used solely in the event of job loss, or for big, sudden expenses lets say a new roof not covered by insurance that you would otherwise go into debt. 36 months is a fairly good measure. This figure is based off your fixed, necessary monthly expenses. Housing, food, utilities, insurance, etc. then multiply it and save it. Most importantly, and why you may have gotten downvoted, the money needs to be liquid. A HYSA is the best place to hold it. Its not an investment. It needs to be accessible at a moments notice. It shouldnt be subject to any kind of market volatility. And should only be used as a last resort, aftwr exhausting all other forms of savings and monies available.

The 36 months of expenses in an emergency fund thing is basic advice intended for people who are not particularly financial savvy and need things stated in extremely simple terms. Since this is rinvesting, this deserves a more nuanced discussion than most of the replies youve received so far have contributed. We should be able to understand things here like opportunity cost, max historic drawdowns of asset classes, etc.. We also should have a good understanding of our actual income and expenses, what the risks are to our income sources, what the value of and risks to our assets are, what expenses can be adjustedeliminated over time in the case of a long term loss of income, etc.. I personally regret having followed the 36 months advice too literally when younger. It was money I never needed and never came close to needing and wouldve grown to much greater levels had I invested it instead. People will respond that I was just lucky and what if, etc., but really it just turns out that in those downtimes, you adapt and adjust and find solutions. Besides myself, I cannot think of any partner, friend, family member, or coworker that I am aware of a situation where they ever needed six months of living expenses within 13 days. Never. I cant even imagine a scenario where that would happen. All of this gets down to specifics of your personal finances and situation, so no blanket statement exists, but I dont think it is hard constructing an investment portfolio for an emergency fund that properly balances risk and return, perhaps bootstrapping it with some percentage of buffer above historic max drawdown for that asset allocation. The fun thing is watching it grow over the years past that buffered amount and beyond, eventually getting to the point where even a historic market crash would leave you better off than if you had played it safe by stashing it in a low percentage rate bank account.

This is a very dangerous way to play the safety net. Why? Because you are relying on credit to make all of your bills. You may not be able to use credit for this. Rent or mortgage may not be paid on a CC, or some other needs. It also likely generates interest on the debt, usually at a high rate. And the effects can manifest in other deleterious ways such as FICO fluctuations. The cashHYSACD or iBond Ladder is easily accessible and will NOT generate interest losses. Cash is king, particularly in an emergency. It is uncoupled from markets for stocks or bonds so is impervious to panic crashes and requires no collateral. Someones ability to pay their basic bills or make minimum payments on debts can be stretched. Using leverage of debt products or assets is not an emergency fund. I will say, in an emergency, paying for the vet bill or car repair or whatever lesser emergency that crops up with a CC is certainly wise, if that CC bill can be paid in full from the emergency fund on time for the statement due date.

replies.text: Someone owns a fraction of a company. They would rather have cash in their pocket. You buy it from them. Now you dont have that cash, but you do have a fraction of a company or with an ETF, smaller fractions of hundreds of companies, and you own a fraction the profits that company makes in the future. Generally, over time, those profits will exceed what you originally paid plus you can sell those shares to someone else at a maybe higher or lower price, like they sold to you.

Lets say you make 5000 a month. Of that, 2000 goes to rent and bills, and 2000 goes to other expenses like groceries and entertainment. This leaves you 1000 a month. At first you want to set aside that 1000 a month in your savings accounts exactly what youre doing until you have about 6 months of expenses saved up in case of emergency, which in this case would be 24,000. The money in your savings account will make a little bit of interest, but thats not an investment. Its more of a loan that youre making to the bank, and theyre giving you a little bit of money for the privilege holding your money. An investment is when you own something of value. You could invest in a car, but the value of that car would likely go down over the years. You could invest in a house, and the value of that house would likely go up over the years. The issue with these investments is that theyre not liquid meaning, you cant really do any much with the change in value. Your car may be worth half of its initial value in 5 years, but that doesnt make you any worse off. Your house could double in value after 10 years, but that doesnt mean you can take a trip to Cabo whenever you want. What most people refer to when they say they want to invest is they want to own part of a business, they want to share in the profits and losses of that business, and they want to be able to sell that part of a business that is, liquidate it to have more liquid money to take a trip to, say, Cabo. You could invest in your own business sink 100,000 into a commercial property that youre renting to clean up, design, and open up a restaurant. If this restaurant is successful, it may make 10,000 a month in profit. Now, you can do one of two things with this profit 1. You can withdraw it, put it in your own bank account and take a flight to Cabo this is called taking a dividend, but be aware that you have now decreased your restaurants value by 10,000 in order to increase your personal wealth by 10,000 2. Or you can use it to build out the patio of your restaurant to accommodate more customers and then make 15,000 a month in profit, so the value of your restaurant has now increased. Now, again, you can either take a dividend, or you can reinvest it into the growth of the company. But starting a restaurant takes a lot of upfront work. Whats a lot easier is buying a part ownership of an already existing business, like the graphics card company NVIDIA or the retail company Costco. If you buy a share of NVIDIA, you are entitled that tiny fraction of value of the company, but you should be aware that its NVIDIAs policy to reinvest its earnings, because its in a growth phase so the value of your shares grows, but you arent making money. If you buy a share of Costco, you are entitled that tiny fraction of value of the company, but you should be aware that Costco pays out dividends because its not in a growth phase so youre making money, while the value of your shares stays the same. Theres no wrong answer, theres just what you want to get out of investing. But what if NVIDIAs competitor AMD comes out with a new technology that absolutely crushes NVIDIA and causes their stock to tank? Its risky to own single stocks. So what you can do instead is buy a share of a mutual fund, which contains hundreds or even thousands of stocks. For example, with my personal excess savings I buy shares of VTSAX, which contains shares of all the publicly traded companies in the United States. It doesnt matter if a couple companies lose value, because Im confident that most companies in the US will be doing well and growing over the time horizon I plan to hold this mutual fund for a couple decades at least enough so to outweigh poorly performing companies. So if you want to invest in a mutual fund, open up an account with a brokerage firm, such as Vanguard, Schwab, or Fidelity, and set up your account to automatically withdraw a certain amount of money each month to buy a broadbased mutual fund like VTSAX or you can buy individual stocks like NVIDIA, or you can buy ETFs, which are somewhere in between. With VTSAX in particular, over the next few months youll see the value go up and down, over the next few years youll see its value go up slightly, and in 1020 years those mutual funds will be worth waaaay more than what you paid for them, so you can sell them and take a hundred flights to Cabo.

Start with your workplace 401k or equivalent and an IRA. Read about what they are, what they do to your taxes, and when you can access the money. Then read about how much you can put into each account every year. Your goal should be to put away as much money as possible into those two accounts as you can and buy a simple target date index fund, where the fund year is near when you turn 75. Buy that one fund every month until you retire.

Youre buying a small piece of a company that entitles you to your small share of any profits the company makes from their business. If people decide that the company is going to make even more money later than it does now, the price of your share goes up because presumably it will pay out more later. If your business goes bankrupt, you lose your money. If youre buying an ETF like of the SP500, its like buying a really tiny slice of a whole bunch of different companies 500, wouldnt ya know, but same principle applies. Buying the SP500 is like putting your eggs in 500 different baskets break a few and you will, but who cares. Keep in mind that every 10 years or so everyone is gonna freak out and drop all the baskets at the same time. Prices will recover but it may take a long time, so investing when you need your money soon is risky.

replies.text: It sounds like you have a fortunate family from a financial standpoint that have all made good long lasting financial relationships and have had success with working with financial advisors to manage their money while they have spent time in the business or work earning enough to have extra to invest. That is a powerful combination they have accomplished. It appears your parents and grandparents have consolidated on a set of accomplished advisors. I would move your money to that set of advisors so it will be together with their future gifts. Frankly as much as you like your financial advisor and how helpful he has been to you, you are not a drop in the bucket in his gross income, so he is losing little financially by you moving away. I suspect you are a likeable guy and he is doing it as much as a friend as anything so will be sad to see you go, but will wish you Godspeed and success as you leave. I spent most of my career in a major broker dealer working in a regional capacity and helping our top teams manage their UHNW clients and their families. It is a fortunate thing to be exposed to the level of help you will get from a large accomplished team of HNW advisors. Enjoy the relationship as it builds.

For 3, if youre willing to put some time in, i would suggest finding an hourly financial advisor when you need consultation then using a financial planning tool like Projection Lab to manage your own financial plan. Thats what my fiance and I do. Projection lab is good for modeling different scenarios and it provides nice graphs using your assetsdebtsincomelife events etc. theres a free sandbox mode if you just want to play around w it

In all honesty all are trying to share your wealth. Some have more people skills than others. I often play one CFP against a llc to keep both on their toes. In your case I believe you should have an small account under family plan. From there you do what you feel like that fits your model. Earlier I dealt direct with each company reinvestment department because of high brokerage fees. Later I consolidated into different accounts in a same brokerage that I can walk in drop off signed documents, deposit and talk to them about tax saving plans. Over the years I had many advisors, stock trader Ivy league graduate and had lunch with branch managers and they asked me if I want to apply for ipo stocks and programs not available to many. Most only do as requested with minimal interaction. The one you had for so many years probably never earned much from you but he is a good source for go to questions. I really do not encourage you putting all your savings with same guy family member works with. Best is avoid giving out too much personal question.

I would avoid using ANY family friend as a financial advisor. Dont mix business with personal relationships. Because when you want to end the relationship, its awkward as you are finding out. I also dont see any benefit to using multiple advisors. If you use an advisor, they need to know the whole picture to make recommendations, not just the part invested with them. To break up, you make it short and sweet Weve decided were going to manage our investments ourselves going forward. We appreciate your help and guidance that got us this far and were ready to take over from here. Then you move the investments to your own account wherever you set it up, such as Fideltity, Schwab, etc. by telling the NEW custodian to move the assets from the old one. When your old advisor sees another company requesting the transfer, they will have already heard from you whats happening. Personally I dont believe there is any magic involved in investing. I personallly follow the Bogleheads philosophy so I dont use an advisor, and that system has done great for me. Easy too.

The value of an advisor is to motivate you to do more and organize and automate you. Your long time sounds like he was just getting started, and he is not pushing you hence not worth it. You should put the names of the firms and what the management fees are, and list the biggest mutual funds just the symbol so you can learn how to look up internals. And there is no etiquette for brokerage, if someone is not providing value, you pull the account to someone who will. Most advisors are mediocre just like most employees in any profession. This is a money game, the is the score, biggest number at the end wins...

When I first started working, I always thought I need a FA for investments and I had even asked my colleagues. I was so naive that I kept all my money in savings account paying almost nothing. I moved from another country so I didnt have any clue on IRA and my employer didnt offer 401k. I researched on my own and eventually opened IRA but still was naive enough to not contribute every year. Eventually, I became more intelligent. Just before Covid hit, I was looking at investing 100k that I had been saving. I thought its a big amount, I need a FA to help me invest properly. I met few but wasnt sold on any. So, I decided to do it on my own and I am glad the portfolio has been doing good. Over the last 4 years it has been at least matching SP. We now have a brokerage account, HSA, 2 Roth IRAs and 2 401ks. All retirement accounts have 3 funds FSELX, FXAIX, and VTI in 106030 allocation. I have also learned to feel, one needs a FA after 5m assets or if getting a 1m inheritance. Not only is that a life changing amount but one also needs to do proper tax planning. In your case, I think it is safe to assume, between your parents, your wifes parents and your grandparents, you two are likely to get significant inheritance combined mid 6 figures or may be even more. Hence, having a relationship with a FA would be beneficial. Id speak with both your grandparents and inlaws FA. Understand their plan, their investment philosophy, fees etc, do some research of my own and then pick one.

replies.text: You will never find anyone who endorses FAs on Reddit. The truth is a good FA can add value in places outside of the portfolio piece if youre with the right people they will take care of your estate planning, run tax efficient strategies tax loss harvesting, QCDs, Roth conversions, etc, and ultimately give you back your time otherwise spent researching, rebalancing, doing the tax loss harvesting yourself, etc. Is 1 worth the 24 weeks per year you spend working this stuff yourself? If no, then forgo the advisor. If yes, then find a CFPCFA that you like and that will do all of the above.

There is only an upside if you are clueless about andor uninterested in learning how to manage money, and would otherwise keep it all in the bank. 1.25 AUM is obscene, but more critically it means youll have a safe withdrawal rate of 2.75 instead of 4. Do you want that? Hard pass on this down to Earth guy hes not auditioning to be your friend. actually worse due to suboptimal, high expense investments vs. basic index funds
Dont need one. Job should be nuked. Its the ultimate nepotism job

Unless youre clueless or actively harming yourself by your trading behavior, the worth its anything to do with portfolio composition or returns. What your paying for is management, running projections, advice on tax efficientcy and withdraw strategies, etc. 99.9 of people dont need these services on an ongoing basis and it would be far less expensive to pay someone as needed when there are significant changes in your circumstances.

You didnt mention how much you have in investments but say you have 5mm, at 1.25 management fees thats 62,500 per year. If you really want to hire an advisor then pay by the hour rather than them managing the whole portfolio. A simple mix of equity index funds and Treasury Inflation Protected Securities would suffice for your portfolio which certainly doesnt require paying 1.25 in management fees a year.

Speaking as a PM, they should only really be used for funds, things that are very complex andor extremely sensitive, or for people who really have no idea what theyre doing and need the help. This precludes a lot of individual investors.

This question has been asked alot. You need a wealth manager, not really a portfolio manager. Wealth managers maximize returns while minimizing tax burdens. They also can help create a budget and plan for future expenses. The last thing is trust. This is the hardest thing retirees need to get their heads around. Your entrusting your older years to a complete stranger and that is very hard. Remember, the wealth manager needs to earn your trust and listen to you when you call with questions. Ive seen people pull millions away from managers that have performed fantastic, because they would not return a call. Plus you dont need to give them your entire nest egg. Let them prove they can do what they say.

Heres the thing. This sub HATES advisors because they think all they do is buy stocks and not beat the market, which isnt what a goodcompetent FAs job really is, so youre not going to get many biased answers. What you should be looking for is someone who will manage your money while constructing an indepth finical plan help with estate planning and manage your tax liability.
The portfolio you gave is a bit worrying. I would suggeest an hourly fee based advisor

My wife and I have a multiple 7 figure net worth. Our FA firm fee only CFP handles all our tax paperwork including representing us if the IRS comes knocking, asset rebalancing, estate planning, helped set up our POAs, wills, trust paperwork, does our IRARoth conversions for us, manages our inherited IRA RMDs, helps us manage our benefit elections, set up all our 529 accounts for the kidsextended family and opened the doors to some accredited investor only investments that are looking to return 2030 or more per year. They have more than earned their fees so far and they make it a point of emphasis to make sure we are comfortable with all the choices and decisions before moving forward.
Hope your best of the bunch brought lube. Those fees are high. You could use vanguard if you even need a FA. Vanguard charges .03 AUM
Theyre not.

They are not worth it. OK, let me rephrase that they are not worth it in terms of which stocks to invest in, but rather as a lifecoach that tells its client to do things more fundamental try to sock away all you can in your 401K IRA, have a certain mix of cash and stocks, etc. But this is something that one can get for free by listening to Dave Ramsey or Suzi or reading a book by them. I suppose that some folks are so weakwilled that they need to fork over a nice chunk of change to someone to tell them the same thing that those gurus do so as to motivate them to actually do it in a sunkcost fallacy type of way.

I think handling keys to your portfolio isnt a paranoia, particularly for independent advisors. Even if you deal with someone reputable, you are unlikely to know well how they approach IT security. For the net performance of 5.12, I think you answered yourself. There are good fixed income opportunities paying you above that.

I used to be in your position once I understood Behavioral Finance and read a white paper by Vanguard on why those with advisors make in avg 3 more annually and realized it.... Buy and hold might work when your young but as you reduce your risks when older you want to have professional advice

This sub hates advisors because they think their only job is to beat the SP. A good advisor at an RIA will be doing far more than investing your money, especially as you near retirement. On the investing side, theyll work with you to create an allocation that fits your risk tolerance. Of course you wont beat the SP over time when youre not 100 equity, but its a myth that managers cannot beat their respective index. Other than investing, theyll work with you on financial planning, tax planning, estate planning, and any questions you have. Many RIAs will have a fee under 1 for 1M plus portfolios.

But...1 is too high for a 7 figure portfolio. Im an FA btw for 30 years. Without telling you my fees, Id suggest 65 bps would be fair for the average client that just needs portfolio construction and ongoing ajustingrebalancing as the world turns, along with the usual questions about distributions and tax planning. Its not that hard, but even smart people have valid questions that a good FA can help with. 1 plus .25 is still nuts. Also, its a fee, not a commission, but you hopefullyprobably know that difference. Commissions died many years ago, unless youre an insurance agent.

replies.text: Custodial Roth IRA and a 592 Education plan. Re search both of those and you should find plenty of places to stash birthday money etc

What we did was set up three funds actually just banks for them.for their monetary gifts when they were young. Fund A was short term, fun things candy, small games, Fund B was medium expensive video games, and Fund C big items that you can only touch when you saved the full amount, like a computer or video game console. The money was split evenly. We also set a UGMA, that mostly grandparents, uncles contributed. If I did it now, it would be a 529 plan. Both are very financially responsible today.

Step 1 when theyre young is teaching them the power of compounding interest. We dont give our kids an allowance, instead they invest in Bank of Dad which pays 5 MONTHLY interest. Theyre quickly understanding the power of compound interest and as their funds ramp up, were slowly introducing various expenses. Once viable well have them invest in a Roth IRA and theyll understand the power of compounding and time in market.
Eligibility for Roth IRA means they have earned income from jobs. Not from chores. It doesnt matter whose money gets put in the account, but the child is filing earned income on a tax return.

What ages are your kids? Investing as a general concept isnt really that difficult. Its the discipline to spend within your means that people typically have issues with. At young ages I think its important for kids to have money and make mistakes. Spend their moneybon something they want, regret and learn to wait until they have enough money to purchase something else. Learning about opportunity costs is a valuable lesson. As they get older you can show them their investment accounts that you manage. How small contributions over time have steadily increased. Maybe when they get their first job you match contributions to an IRA to help build the habit. Lots of ways to get to a positive end result. Continue to have age appropriate talks about money and they will be more prepared than most. Not sure apps for investing would be good for kids. It might play into a desire to trade everyone wants a quick buck, especially kids. Learning to invest for the long term is what is critical.

I tried using stocks or apps etc...but it didnt work well. What really resonates with kids is what they can see and touch and feel. So, gold and silver coinsbars have worked well. My kids are up 50 already on their silver
They by silver and gold coins with the money they get? Those appreciate with time?

replies.text: There are all kinds of vulture funds buying up lottery payouts, medical liability settlements, bankruptcy settlements, and yes pre IPO shares. These funds just do financial analysis and are paying out a discounted present value on the shares. From the sellers point of view, it is just an early liquidity exit. If you wish to hold, then dont sell. Its not some kind of trick. Think about it this way. You can apply for early social security and receive a lower payout, or wait and get a higher payout. Its up to you.
You have to check if you can sell your shares to an unaffiliated entitiy. You probably cannot.

Do you have shares because you are an employee of the company? And do you have shares or ISONSOs? Your share agreement will dictate whether you can sell the shares and how can do it. Sometimes it could be a good reason to sell at least some of the shares to cover the acquisition costs or the taxs you may have already paid if these were NSOs originally which you exercised. A private transaction can take some time. And there is normally a transaction expense if the transaction goes through a private placement broker that expense can be higher. The people reaching out to you could be anyone from a private placement broker to VC fund to family office to accredited individual investor, etc. Their goals are going to be all different.

Generally preIPO shares arent allowed to be sold right away. Occasionally that works out for regular employees GOOG, usually it doesnt. If people are trolling you to buy your shares I assume yours are immediately executable?
that analogy makes sense thank you. I can see how they are vultures trying to scoop up shares at a discount

I am a former employer, so I had to purchase the ISO shares when I exited the company. I assume Ill have to wait something like 6 months once they go public to sell them, but not sure if those rules only apply to current employees, or if its anyone with ISO shares.

I did sell shares to a vulture fund once and had a good experience. I was a lead plaintiff in a bankruptcy settlement regarding the failure of a brokerage firm. The litigation extended over 4 years and involved hundreds of thousand of my money being tied up. Towards the end of the process, I was offered 90 precent plus settlement by several vulture firms. I sold rather than wait another year or two and it was professional and satisfactory to me. I also had a consulting client who was an insurance company that had a fund that engaged in these kinds of investments. It was on the up and up, although yes it does appear to be shady. There are probably less than honest operators so do your diligence. Good luck.

How confident are you that there will be an IPO? That should be part of your decisioning in whether you want to engage is a private secondary transaction. During the IPO process the shares convert. There may or may not be a lock up period. Depends on the class of share. But if you are a former employee if the company does go public and the stock is optionable usually after a week or two you can create a collar on your shares if you are concerned about postIPO euphoria causing the price of the shares to decline by the end of the lockup period.
Thats good to know there are good experiences out there. This way you could live you life and not have to wait several years for the legal to shake out.

The stock market is stupendously overvalued by historical standards. The US debt is stupendously high by historical standards. Thats probably not a coincidence. The US hasnt experienced a true multiyear bear market since the 70s. Ever since the the US kicked off its 45 year deficit spending under Reagan, stock markets have been levitating. Even at the worst moment of the Great Recession crash, stock prices merely flirted with their longterm fair value. Otherwise theyve been floating on sunshine. Weve seen the past 23 years how a sudden surge in deficit spending can cause asset inflation. But the 45 years of Federal borrowing likewise caused asset inflation, albeit not as sharp and spiky as recent inflation, and helped keep stock prices overvalued for most of my lifetime. That was possible because 45 years of rising debt was canceled out by 45 years of falling interest rates. The two led to a fairly stable interest payment. Now that debt is exploding while interest rates are high, interest payments are likely to devour the Federal budget in coming years, forcing Congress to pass some form of debt reduction. When that day gets here, the 45 year old stock market boom is heading for a slaughter of historical proportions.

PEPriceEarnings is a ratio of market prices to earnings. In rational environment one would expect that price would be a function of earnings discounted to risk free interest rates. If earnings were 10x the 2014 earnings in 2024, one would expect prices to be 10x of those from 2014, if interest rates were held constant. This scenario holds if 1 Markets are rational, and 2 I terest rates are unchanged amongst other points. We can all agree that given our WSB friends that markets tend to be highly irrational at times and this would manifest in higher prices with unchanged levels of earnings. I think you could contend that current valuations arent rational given expectations of real expected returns over the coming quarters.

Lets look at an example 5y Schiller for easier visualization Earnings in the previous 5 years 0 2 4 8 16, price 32 PE 2, Schiller 5.5 Earnings in previous 5 years 6 6 6 6 6, price 32 PE 6, Schiller 5.5 In both cases the Schiller index is 5.5 but one case of is a high flying market with 100 YoY growth, the other of a stagnant earnings market. Schiller CAPE obviously needs to be higher in the second scenario. Schiller 5.5 Schiller 5.5 when last year earnings are enormous and the earnings from 10y ago are irrelevant. Originally it was created to smooth out 12 year drops in earnings over recessions, not to smooth out enormous 10y growth in earnings. These dont just drop by 80 and stay there.

My financial advisor told me the same information that you can write off up to 3,000 of regular income from Capital losses and then any other Capital losses can only be applied to capital gains, but you can keep track and carry over more Capital losses to write off up to 3000 from your regular income the next year as well

Of course its true. This is a basic tenet of tax loss harvesting. After offsetting capital gains, remaining loss can offset ordinary income up to 3000 per year, and any further remaining amounts being able to be carried forward to future tax years.
I think this depends on the tax rules of a country. I know for sure in Canada capital losses cant offset normal income except year of death. The 3k rule someone mentioned applies in US.
Its absolutely true.

replies.text: Someone with more experience should weigh in, but I think you are limited to reporting 3k per year in losses related to stocks. I believe there is a way to spread it out over years, but not familiar with this method.

What youre talking about is referred to as tax loss harvesting. If you want to do it I do it at the end of the year, I would only sell 17k of the gains and use the remaining 3k loss to reduce your ordinary income. Hold off on purchasing the same or substantially similar stock within 30 days before or after the sale of a stock you sold at a loss, otherwise the sale will be classified as a wash sale and you wont be able to claim the loss.
If we lose Capitol, investments will be our last problem
The 3k limit applies to capital loses applied to ordinary income in a tax year. You can put any amount of capital losses against capital gains in a year.
Thats only for losses, if you sell stock, incur a gain and rebuy, then the gain is not a wash sale
Thank you for this, very helpful!
Thanks, this helps!

If you in my opinion correctly fear an incoming recession, the best play is to derisk from stocks and increase your allocation into safe bonds US treasuries and AAAAA. The shorter the period here the lower the short term price changes you can expect, the longer the time period, the more upside ifwhen interest rates fall. You dont have to time the market perfectly, but at least by reducing your exposure to stocks relative to your portfolio, you can buy back in after a crash for cheap by moving from bonds back to stocks. Alternatively you can stay in the stock market, but just buy yourself some long term puts theyre particularly cheap now that vix volatility is low and interest rates are still high. Buying in at the top right before a recession is the easiest way to see your money do nothing for 410 years.

Then, when it is on sale, you decide to buy unsalted butter just in case GOOG. Sure it isnt exactly the same, but it isnt really different enough to deal with the slight variations

Forget the technology terminology. In selling CPUs the only thing that really matters is the ratio of performance to power consumptionheat. If you have a good ratio you will be the market leader. If you have a bad ratio you will have to slash prices to remain competitive to get people to accept the powerheat failings. This is universally true for consumer, enterprise, and data center. They all have reasons to want to minimize power draw and heat. Aside from CPUs, Intel deciding to get into the GPU market right when another GPU maker exploded in value is bad timing for them.

Because of the concern of reissuance, the goal of share buybacks is to lower the number of slices of the pie. The pie stays the same size so each slice of the pie is worth more. In other comments you mention treasury shares are not counted towards number of slices. This is only true from an accounting perspective. The financial reality is probability based. If the company has 1 million Treasury shares, and a 50 chance to issue them, the market will discount each shares value as if it was 0.5 million shares were issued. 10 chance, then 0.1 million shares. Put yourself as CEO of a company, if you tell your shareholder we are buying back shares but we are holding them as treasury shares, what your shareholders hear is We are buying these shares and are probably going to reissue the shares at a later date so you will spend the same amount cash to buy the shares but get less increase in stock price for doing so. Your bonus as CEO is dependent on the stock price increasing, so you will usually do what increases the stock price most which is cancelling the shares.

If you cancel shares you increase the value of the remaining shares and make shareholders happy. If you buy for the treasury than the same number of shares are still outstanding so you do not increase the value of the remaining shares. Its reverse dilution when canceling the shares. This is sort of a ELI15
if you cancel the shares, EPS goes up.

Assuming that a stock buyback increases the remaining stock value by the same amount as would be paid out per share in dividend... it has tax advantages. The tax is deferred until shares are sold and then the additional profit can be offset with negative capital gains, which is not the case with dividends received, as those are taxed immediately taken before you even receive the money. But it very much depends on realistic valuation of the company. NVDA buybacks are a joke at the moment and investors would likely be better off receiving the money in dividend even being taxed immediately. However, companies resort to stock buybacks due to executive bonuses based on stock price performance, not just because of the shareholders themselves.
