The DD is indeed bending reality. In addition to Vogtle 34, there was another project that survived the postFukushima wipeout of US new nuclear builds. That was V C Summer 23, another pair of AP1000s. Westinghouse was so far behind schedule and over budget in building these four plants that it went bankrupt. Thats why a private equity firm like Brookfield owns them in the first place before it sold half to Comeco. The V C Summer utility decided not to continue, but the Vogtle utility did, at great cost. Its because of this experience and the fact that wind and especially solar are far cheaper these days that no one is looking to build more AP1000s, or any other large nuclear reactors, in the US. Europe has had similar experiences in France, Finland, and the UK. Among nonauthoritarian countries in the last couple of decades, only South Korea has managed to build large nuclear reactors on a reasonable budget and schedule. Id be very wary of all the hype around nuclear, be it uranium, SMRs, or large reactors.

Oh, the AP1000 is a great design, as youll see downthread on the other reply to my comment. Definitely the best LWR design currently on the market. But the nuclear industry always claims that theyll learn their lessons and the next build will be smoother and on time and budget. And it never is. Basically every plant built in the 70s and 80s in the US had huge overruns, and many were cancelled after TMI. Even Watts Bar took much longer to complete than expected. Flamanville in France and Olkiluoto in Finland were similar. Frances original build out in the 70s was similarly over. Taiwan ended up cancelling the ABWRs in Longmen, and that was after a dozen or so were built in Japan. Unless youre an authoritarian country, or maybe South Korea, youre very likely to take far more money and time to build every large nuclear reactor. This time wont be different. This is unfortunately why the nuclear industry, which should be a perfect complement to solar and wind, and perfect for AI, is instead a sunset industry.

I would not say it is a mistake in my analysis, it is your opinion. Whether it goes up or down is a bit of a coin flip. Even if it goes up it does not prove your assumption is correct. I do not think institutional investors are that lazy not to look at where the numbers might come from, but who knows. Edit I asked ChatGPT, here is what he has to say Unrealized capital gains from investments in other companies are not typically included in the earnings per share EPS of the parent company. EPS generally reflects the companys net income from its core business activities, and unrealized capital gains are considered part of other comprehensive income OCI, not net income. ... In summary, unrealized capital gains on investments in other companies do not typically affect EPS if investing is not the companys main business. Instead, these gains are recorded in OCI. They only affect EPS if they are realized i.e., the investments are sold or if the company uses the equity method to account for the earnings of its investees.

TLDR Early March 2020 Hesitated to invest in masks due to market chaos. A trusted supplier offered KN95 masks, leading to first order of 250,000 masks. Market was chaotic stories of buyers offering cash directly at factories. First order sold quickly, yielding 172,600 in profit. Second shipment 1 million masks sold, earning 1.57 million in profit. Third shipment 1.06 million masks and 20,000 gowns sold, adding 1.08 million in profit. Total profit from first three shipments 2.83 million. Fourth shipment 5.15 million masks planned, costing 11.12 million. U.S. government regulation and market collapse caused 5 million loss, wiping out previous profits. Overall, despite 13.87 million in total sales, ended with significant losses.

If you overlay interest rates overtime onto a chart with TREE, it essentially trades completely inverse to interest rates. I doubt its quite that simple. Their best financial performance was FY 2019 when they recognized 1.1B in revenue and their stock price hit 450 in June of that year. the fed rate in 619 was 2.4. From there, rates were lowered to basically 0over the next year, and kept there for the next two years until rate increases began mid 22. During that time the value of lending tree stock fell from 450 to 60. Again, the interest rate was basically 0 for the entire time. TREE was one of many overly hyped fintech stocks carrying a PE over 250 at its peak. Their financial performance never met the hype and the price fell as a result. As interest rates went down, so did their revenue. I expect them to do better moving forward, but I doubt the market rewards them with such ridiculous valuations again.

You were the one who suggested in another comment that IonQ could have a proprietary QML algorithm. I would be interested in hearing the talks this week because I am not familiar with Yamadas work. For all of your talk that I am making too many blanket statements, you are assuming an awful lot about my professional experience. I would not idolize this industry if I were you Ive learned more in my two years out of private industry than my time in it. Ive also been able to stay more up to date. You say its incredible to think that QC cant help with AI, Id argue the exact opposite. 1 ML is inherently a big data problem, something QC is bad at because youd need to load in and read out data. Part of the reason factoring is such a good problem for QC is because it is relatively easy to load a 2048 bit integer. Whereas in ML youd probably have to load your training data, which would be expensive if you have a lot. 2 maybe youd be looking at solving some optimization problem related to training, at best that would have a Grover sqrt type speedup which would quickly get eaten by error correction overhead rendering it practically useless 3 current methods use variational quantum circuits and classically optimize them, which have no fundamental speedup and people can only point to heuristic improvements. These are on toy problems essentially. For large scale ML this would probably not work at all I mean youre free to consider this a larp and invest in this company with your current knowledge. With what I know about QC, I wouldnt. Then again I missed the crazy price spike this month so what do I know

Long vol ETFs are not a good way to trade vol and their derivatives are worse. If you want to go long vol, buy long dated index puts. If you want to short vol, long a short vol etf. If you are trading a derivative on a long vol etf you are trading vol the etf of vol the derivative of vol your option of an index. Thats fucking stupid and nobody could understand it and anybody that thinks they could is wrong.

You have a point but it all depends on whether the futures curve for the VIX is going to stay in backwardation. The ETFs hold futures on the VIX, so your strategy is really dependent on the futures curve. Also, you have to really consider basis risk, which is the risk that the price of the derivative is not going to reflect the conditions seen in the underlying. Ive seen this happen and Ive suffered from this many times. If you really want to put in a curve trade on volatility, youre better off doing it with futures and not options. And of course, you need to hedge or youll get blown up.
Check what happens if the etfs do a reverse split due to the decay.

What I am saying is that the information and their comparisons are very outdated as Microsoft has aggressively opened the throughput for the OpenAI models. One thing I will quibble with is that api limit is related to inference speed because it is throughput. In a way it is expected throughput as well. Heres what I mean. Previously when you used LLMs in Azure you would get a warning for tokens you could generate per minute if you went over the limit and then outright rate limiting would 404 your requests going forward. Now, to your point latency is what we are really talking about here. What I can tell you is that each model has its own latency expectations that Microsoft never publishes because if youre on a pay as you go service you are effectively on a shared service. What I can tell you is that 4 was terrible, 4turbo was a little better, 4o is a lot better and 4omini is perfect. In terms of latency. 4omini is a smaller param model. Tokens are complex especially in an enterprise environment. I am passing thousands of tokens through expecting thousands of tokens back on complex queries. With that said, if you really are comparing apples to apples small model versus small moel I think their claims fall apart and thats my point.

Nobody uses Azure on a shared or dedicated service with a single GPU. Youre missing the point of how this works. GPUs are typically connected through NVLINK and networking, which increases throughput and reduces latency. With more powerful and interconnected GPUs, latency decreases, and throughput improves. In this way, throughput and latency are related, especially when processing complex models. Since the new GPTo1, many factors influence speed and throughput behind the scenes, and they do indeed relate.

Training will never be on par with inference until models can be trained instantly, which is just a fact. But youre right that workloads are shifting more towards inference. That said, the models doing the inference still need to be trained. Training is timebased, while inference is an ongoing, aggregate usage over time. As chips get faster, training times will drop, and inference will grow. But with future data and models being larger and more complex, who knows how training will pan out. At some point, training will be good enough and modular training will come into play, allowing realtime updates, while inference handles the queries and keeps adding to that longterm memory.

Im not sure what you mean by unregulated. Why would you think this business reverses? They have the largest market share for the app market. Google buys from them for example. This business has been growing every quarter for many years. They do rely on google and apple app stores which is a clear negative but given pressure from regulators in Europe and US wa potential justice department breakup of google, they wont F with Applovin their hands tied and cant be viewed as monopolistic. IMO this is a unique time where there is a window for Applovin to become much bigger. In terms of insider selling, a lot of these sales are for tax net settling of shares. But yes many others have been outright selling. CEO still owns billions of stock and many insiders still own large amount of shares relative to what they sold. KKR doesnt count, they 10x their money and their fund vintage was ending, so they needed to sell. You can also make same argument for META or NVDA, ton of insider selling there. Also the valuation isnt even close to bloated. They report GAAP earnings but if you add back amortization and stock based comp like every peer does, they are trading low 20s PE for a business growing 20 wvery high incremental margins. Thats very inexpensive in this market.

What I mean by unregulated is the distinct way that they facilitate the collection of invaluable private data and improve targeting by doing so....which is the lions share of the value. I really do like the notion that we live in a time where an upstart like Applovin could forge their own market share amidst the big dogs. I will always be FOR that...however the behavior of the founders and csuite does not reflect a solid alignment with this end goal. They would not sap billions from the coffers at their first opportunity, when their company may need all the help and good will that it can get over the coming quarters. I do not believe that large funds give an eff about this company beyond the extent to which they can accumulate and distribute shares over and over again, kinda like the apparent behavior of the principals of the company. I rarely see advertising companies showcasing that. Big funds do care. Thats why the stock is moving because you have institutional buying this up. Its also big enough to be added to SP 500 so its just a matter of time.

If you look at their SDK, the beauty of it becomes quite clear. It is on the advertiser to promise to collect and make proper use of the data....down to the age and precise location. You have full access to it, you need to pass a variable to us saying that you have been given permission by the user to use it, and we trust you. With or without the actual consent, it can be used. There is no true protection....just a loose legal framework to cover their ass. Ai.....blah, blah, blah.....THIS is the secret sauce. Similar to the dilution by vesting disclaimer and clawback policy found buried in their quarterlies only after facing legal action from shareholders it is the same pattern.....smoke...meet mirrors. All good things must come to an end..... This is just a public service announcement. I no longer have a horse in this race. If this DD saves one person from getting burned....it was totally worth it.

What time scale are you tradingholding on? Id look for a way to slow down the exit and give you a minute to see its ok. My suggestion is to write down a few exit rules. Like a x drop sustained for y minutes, OR a 2x drop. Obviously whatever rules you choose must be tailored to your strategy.

Maybe set a stop loss that goes up as you make a profit, or you could sell a percentage of your contracts at certain profit levels. For example have sell 50 of your contracts when you hit 50 profit, 25 when you hit 75 profit, and the remaining 25 when you hit 100 profit. You could also try to trade on paper simultaneously to see how good your analysis is in regards to figuring out when its time to buy or sell.

Think about it this way If you take profit now, you will have a little extra cash. Tomorrow, youll bet it all again and possibly lose it all. So... why not just hold now if youre going to risk losing it all again tomorrow? Not financial advice.

Think about exiting in waves. At 2030 close some of your position. Then, close another chunk at 50 gain or 75. Then finally close everything at 100 or 200. Obviously youll want to risk manage as well so if youre at 60 gain and you dont like the price action just close whatever is left. But the idea is the basically have a strategy for taking gains and stick to it. Ideally after the first 2030 you close enough to be able to avoid that ever being a losing trade. Then have kind of have pure upside.

Well, this depends on how often the trades run higher. Or what it ranges at once it goes over your Depending on that, you can probably do a ratio. For example, let assume you buy two contracts at 1.00. If the price runs up to 1.30, you exit one contract to take the 30 gain. And for the second contract, you can choose to set a stop of 0.70. This will make the trade a breakevennot including commissions. Depending on how confident you are, you can choose to set the stop at 0.8, 1.0, 1.1,etc. All of them will give you a different pnl. So, the main thing here would be assessing how confident you are. The purpose of the first contract is basically to give you room for bigger moves if its possible. Scale up as needed. Alternatively, and Im paraphrasing here, git gud. Fine tune the setups your spot and set up extra trading rules to justify your exit at 30,50, etc. If the stock movement only complies with enough rules for a 20 exit.. then exit at 20.. and so on.

Getting burnt for 100k is telling. Hitting 100 is great but can you afford for it to expire worthless? If so then try holding to 50 profit and cash out until you get your nerves and emotions under control. Then itll be easier to hold during the dips while you wait for higher returns. Remember that nothing is fool proof and what may seem like a temporary pull back may last longer than you expect. You can also pull out profit at 20 so you wont walk away empty handed but obviously this will reduce future gains.

Confidently holding comes down to a few things. Keeping your position size correct. So that you arent terrified of pullbacks. And playing your thesis correctly. Have your levels ready before you enter a trade. Both where you expect it to go. And where its clearly going the wrong direction. So that you know when to cut. Scaling in and or out of a position also helps. I had 4 NVDA 102p yesterday for example. Bought at. 25. I sold 2 at .40. Taking off most of my risk. And leaving 2 to go for my thesis. Then I sold 1 more at .50. Gaurenting me a 30 profit. While still leaving a final runner that I held to .75.

Use studies to get you a better idea of where it might be headed. Obviously doesnt always work, but can still help with decision making. Just this week I held NVDA puts until Friday, even though they were not doing so well on Thursday. The chart was indicating more downside, so I said fuck it and held on, went from potential loss, to 300 gain. I use TTM squeeze, RSI, MACD, CCI, and moving averages 15, 50, 200. Unexpected events will still fuck you though.

You secure a small win that will offer your protection, and will boost your confidence. Your first trade of the day imo needs to be a small conservative gain, that offers enough support in case your second trade goes bad. Also, buy in the money so that if you hold for longer you dont lose to much value in case of pullbacks or price stalls. And finally, stop trying to catch the whole movement, and be happy with your gains, if you take options as a quick rich scheme you will get burned, its a slow and steady, and you will eventually will be able to scale up, to the point where a small conservative win will allow you to take money.

I find on my 9 years of tradingnote that I also work on a banks treasury trading floor, that waiting until on your tp is bullshit, you gotta take partials at major places. my trading senior 35 years of exp says this and I woke up from those big win trades.He says the profit looks nicer on your pants rather than on your dreams.I have no emotion whatsoever on my trades.If its not going in my way for an hour, I take stops instantly, I do not care, just take stop, it looks fine again in 5 min, yeah I open the trade again, if goes bad close again.But if its on profit, I let it ride, give it a time but take partials min half the first time.It gives me relief.Than watch it, the moment it doesnt go on my way, I take half again.And so on.All about managing your emotions and be realistic on the screen.

I have the same feeling what i tell myself is 2030 gains is better than 2030 loss just remember gains are gains get out of the mentality that itll be great to become an overnight millionaire treat it like a job instead of like gambling. Set yourself a goal per day, per week and per month of what you want to make trading long as your reaching within 1020 of that be happy. Lastly trade based on how much you have and how much your willing to lose per trade people typically talk about ratios like 41 ie i want to make 2000 off this trade but am willing to lose 500. With this strategy you only have to be correct 25 of the time to break even anything higher and you are making money that you otherwise wouldnt have. With this strategy as your account grows that 2000 may become 20,000 200,000 2,000,000 but having a system is where you consistently make money and not worry about a loss here or there.

With every trade you have a plan. Stick to the plan. When to take profits, when to cut losses. There is no magic 8 ball. Your 100k is gone, get it out of your head. You have a strategy that works, continue to hit singles all day. Singles win ballgames. If you dont have a plan. Every time you trade, you are firing from the hip and FOMO can happen.

Build selfconfidence in your trading skills. Im in a similar position where I lost like 50 when I first started got some back, pulled some out for house buying during early COVID but since that mistake Ive 2xd SP over the last three years. Heres what worked for me 1. Get good at reading price action across multiple time scales, and multiple indicators, simultaneously. I look to make plays where monthly, weekly, daily, and ideally hourly candle patterns and RSIEMA bounces all line up. That helps me know clearly what trading range Im looking at. If I dont have an obvious ressitancesupport level Im playing off, I dont enter the trade. 2. Set very clear, and tight, mental stop losses, and dont enter trades where you cant set them, no matter what your gut says. Because gut feelings are amorphous, you cant argue effectively with them leads to confusion which causes anxiety and FOMO or panic about downside. As a general rule, I dont allow myself more than a 2030 downside on trades, ideally less. Dont mess around with trades where bidask takes you outside that risk. 3. Have a clear understanding of macroeconomics, global money flows, and how they relate to business cycles across different sectors, countries, currencies. Use that macro knowledge to check you technicals. 4. No pennies, clinical trial bio stocks, startups, IPOs, or other PD prone sectors. Dilution risk is way too high and impossible to predict. 5. Last, and most important, do your research after market close, and write down your plays in advance. Doesnt have to be a lot, just a few line touchstone in a note taking app. Crystallized your thoughts and makes expectations explicit, so when you are nervousemotional you can doublecheck your current gut with your reasoned opinion.

Think about your positioning and sizing. If youre able to buy multiple cons, take trims along the way up but leave a few runners so you can capture the 10 bagger. On pullbacks, learn to trust your chart. You likely entered a position because you saw a set up you liked. Wait for an invalidation of your set up or for your stop loss to hit before exiting. Either way, nobody went broke taking profits. Nobody went broke using a stop loss.

the problem with taking profits too soon, is that the math works against you over the long haul even though you might get a lot of smaller winning trades in the short term. the lack of larger winning trades will limit your profitability. i would recommend tracking trades by R. if your trading plan has you aiming for 2R trades on average, then you need to be tracking and looking for setups that can achieve that. once you get used to thinking in that way and you are hitting consistent results in line with your plan, you can simply scale up.

The first rule of options is you never ever ever buy them. Youre always short. Doesnt matter if its calls or puts youre always short. This alone puts theta in your favor. You can trade brackets, support and resistance levels, expected moves, trends. Basically the first thing you want to set up is what securities or indexes youre going to trade. I recommend a large ones that are very liquid and arent going to do crazy things on you. TLT for example, we have a positive trend, we know rates are going lower so any type of pullback, especially a juicy one like 95 to 96 which we might not get, you short the 95 or 100 put, the higher value the put is the more time you want to give yourself. For example back when TLT was trading at 90 I set up a chain of shorts into 2026 with expirations between 90 and 115. Where am I wrong on this trade? Any type of reacceleration in inflation. Already up bigly though so any type of hint that anything isnt slowing, you start covering what youre up on. You do the same thing with companies. If you want high volatility, you have palantir, you have Nvidia, many others, stocks around 30100 typically are going to have a lot of action if they are movers. Short puts on selloffs, sell calls against your stock on rallies. You basically create a cash generator If you do dumb shit like long options, buying calls and buying puts. You have to realize that youre walking into a casino at that point and gambling so if you play lottery tickets and you actually win, stop playing. Ideally you set up your hands when there is some kind of catalyst for your gamble to actually work. When theres an actual strategy that over the next few days or week or something theres some event thats going to move it in your direction but you have to treat it like a lottery ticket, its not investing, if you hit a big one you can turn 1,000 into 50k and many people have done it. The problem is, when they go to try it the second time and the third and the 4th and now theyre back to 1,000. If you ever win one of these, youre not good, you got lucky So if you actually want to make money, read this, if you want to go broke, this sub is very good at teaching people how to do so

This advice is misguided. Confidence relies on how well you know your setup, whether your play is a fiveyear investment or a fiveminute day trade. You gain confidence to hold through pullbacks once you develop confidence in your setup strategy. That means you develop an exit strategy where you predetermine how much of a pullback you are willing to endure, considering a balance between your ideal riskreward ratio and your personality. Understand that some people are better at playing shorter timeframes while others are better at holding for longer. You need to define what makes you feel worse Missing out on those potential gains you couldve made, or seeing a profitable play become a losing play. Once you know, you shouldnt focus on how to make yourself withstand the biggest pain. Instead, focus on how to maximize your returns on the one youre inherently more comfortable with. In other words, you are assuming that you could make more money if you learned how to hold for longer. But in reality, you might do better if you keep getting out early, but you instead play with a bigger size or simply make more of those plays. Whats the benefit of risking and holding out for a play that makes 100 if you can instead make four plays that make 25?
Aka close your eyes or use rules for risky management stuff
